definitions: treat someone with disrespect by ignoring or showing indifference towards them
insult or offend someone by treating them as unimportant or insignificant
examples: She felt slighted when her colleagues ignored her contributions
The host slighted several guests by forgetting their names
His dismissive comments slighted her professional achievements terribly
They deliberately slighted him by not inviting him to the meeting

definitions: make oneself thinner by dieting or exercising to lose weight
reduce the size or number of something to make it smaller
examples: She's been slimming for months to fit into her wedding dress
Many people slim down during summer to look better at the beach
The company slimmed its workforce by twenty percent last year
They need to slim the budget before the fiscal year ends

definitions: throw something somewhere with force using a swinging motion
hang or suspend something loosely from a support or across something
carry or support something using a sling or strap device
examples: He slung his bag over his shoulder and left quickly
The angry customer slung the product across the counter
She slung the hammock between two trees in the garden
They slung ropes across the canyon to build a bridge
The injured player had to sling his arm for several weeks
Mothers traditionally sling their babies while working in the fields

definitions: lose one's footing and slide unintentionally on a surface
move somewhere quietly and quickly without being noticed
gradually decline in quality, standard, or position over time
escape from someone's attention or memory without being noticed
examples: She slipped on the icy pavement and hurt her knee
The soap slipped from his hands into the bathtub
The thief slipped through the shadows without making a sound
She slipped out of the meeting before anyone noticed
Sales have been slipping steadily for the past three quarters
His grades started slipping after he lost interest in school
The important detail slipped my mind during the presentation
Several errors slipped past the editors before publication

definitions: make a long narrow cut or opening in something
cut something open with a long straight incision deliberately
examples: She carefully slit the envelope open with a letter opener
The surgeon slit the skin to access the underlying tissue
The attacker slit the canvas painting with a sharp knife
Workers slit the bags to empty their contents quickly

definitions: spill or splash liquid carelessly or in large amounts
walk or move through wet or muddy ground making splashing sounds
examples: He slopped coffee all over his desk while rushing
The waiter slopped soup onto the tablecloth by accident
The pigs slopped through the muddy pen after the rain
We had to slop through knee-deep water to reach shore

definitions: have or take an inclined position at an angle from horizontal
move somewhere quietly or furtively, especially to avoid something
examples: The garden slopes gently down towards the lake
The roof slopes at a thirty-degree angle for drainage
He sloped off early from work without telling anyone
The teenagers sloped away when they saw the police approaching

definitions: put something into a space where it fits exactly
assign someone or something to a particular time or position
examples: She slotted the coin into the vending machine carefully
The mechanic slotted the new part into place perfectly
They slotted her presentation into the afternoon schedule
The coach slotted him into the starting lineup immediately

definitions: shed or cast off dead skin or tissue naturally
get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary from one's life
examples: Snakes slough their skin several times during their lifetime
The wound will slough dead tissue as it heals naturally
She finally sloughed off her negative attitudes about change
The company needs to slough outdated business practices immediately

definitions: reduce speed or cause something to move at a lower speed
delay or hinder the progress or development of something
examples: The driver slowed down when approaching the school zone
Heavy traffic slowed our journey by almost two hours
The economic downturn slowed growth in the technology sector
Bad weather slowed construction of the new building considerably

definitions: hit someone or something hard with a closed fist
drink something, especially alcohol, in large gulps or amounts
examples: The boxer slugged his opponent with a powerful right hook
He slugged the punching bag to release his frustration
They slugged beer all night at the bachelor party
She slugged down the medicine despite its terrible taste

definitions: live in poor or squalid conditions in overcrowded areas
visit poor or less prestigious places for entertainment or experience
examples: Many families are forced to slum in terrible conditions
They slummed in cramped apartments without proper facilities
Rich tourists sometimes slum it to experience authentic culture
The celebrities were slumming at the local dive bar

definitions: sleep peacefully and quietly, especially for a long period
remain inactive or dormant for an extended period of time
examples: The baby slumbered peacefully through the entire night
She slumbered deeply after the exhausting journey home
The volcano has slumbered for over three hundred years
The economy slumbered through decades of poor management

definitions: fall or sink suddenly and heavily into a position
undergo a sudden severe or prolonged decline in value or activity
sit or lean heavily with poor posture showing exhaustion
examples: He slumped to the ground after finishing the marathon
The defeated boxer slumped against the ropes exhausted
Sales slumped by forty percent during the recession
The stock market slumped following the announcement yesterday
She slumped in her chair after the long meeting
Students often slump at their desks during boring lectures

definitions: pronounce words indistinctly by running sounds together carelessly
make damaging or insulting remarks about someone's character
perform musical notes smoothly connected without separation between them
examples: He slurred his words after drinking too much wine
The patient slurred her speech following the stroke
The politician slurred his opponent with false accusations
She felt hurt when coworkers slurred her ethnic background
The violinist beautifully slurred the notes in the passage
Jazz singers often slur notes to create smooth transitions

definitions: hit someone or something sharply with the palm of hand
make a sharp sound by bringing two things together forcefully
strongly suggest or have a trace of a particular quality
examples: She smacked the mosquito on her arm quickly
The mother smacked her child's hand away from the stove
He smacked his lips after tasting the delicious soup
The waves smacked against the boat's hull repeatedly
His explanation smacks of dishonesty and deception
The proposal smacks of desperation rather than careful planning

definitions: feel or cause a sharp stinging pain, especially from injury
feel upset or distressed from criticism or disappointment
examples: The antiseptic made the cut smart for several minutes
My eyes smart from the smoke in the room
She still smarts from the harsh criticism she received
He was smarting over his rejection from the team

definitions: break something into pieces violently and noisily by impact
hit or strike something with great force causing damage
defeat utterly or destroy completely in competition or conflict
examples: The vandals smashed windows throughout the abandoned building
She accidentally smashed the vase against the doorframe
The tennis player smashed the ball over the net
The car smashed into the barrier at high speed
Our team smashed the opposition five goals to nil
The army smashed through enemy defenses within hours

definitions: spread a greasy or sticky substance over a surface carelessly
damage someone's reputation by spreading false accusations publicly
examples: The child smeared chocolate all over her face and clothes
He smeared sunscreen across his shoulders before swimming
The tabloids smeared the politician with baseless allegations
Rivals tried to smear her reputation before the election

definitions: perceive or detect the odor of something using the nose
emit or have a particular odor that can be perceived
detect or become aware of something suspicious or hidden
examples: She could smell fresh bread baking in the kitchen
The dog smelled the treat hidden in my pocket
The garbage smells terrible after sitting in the heat
These flowers smell wonderful in the evening
I smell trouble brewing between those two departments
The detective could smell corruption in the organization

definitions: extract metal from ore by heating and melting in a furnace
examples: The factory smelts iron ore to produce steel products
Ancient civilizations learned to smelt copper thousands of years ago
Workers smelt aluminum using an electrolytic process today
The company smelts precious metals from electronic waste

definitions: form a pleased or amused expression with the corners of mouth upturned
express approval or favor through facial expression or manner
examples: She smiled warmly when she saw her old friend
The baby smiled for the first time yesterday morning
Fortune smiled upon them during their business venture
The weather smiled on us for the outdoor wedding

definitions: inhale and exhale the smoke of tobacco or other substances
emit smoke or visible vapor from burning or heat
preserve or flavor food by exposing it to smoke from burning wood
examples: He quit smoking after twenty years of cigarettes
She smokes only occasionally at social gatherings now
The chimney was smoking heavily during the cold winter
The volcano has been smoking for several days
They smoke salmon using traditional oak wood chips
The restaurant smokes its own meats every morning

definitions: make a surface even and regular by removing bumps or wrinkles
make something easier or less complicated to accomplish
remove problems or difficulties from a situation or process
examples: She smoothed the wrinkled bedsheets before the guests arrived
The carpenter smoothed the wood with fine sandpaper
The new software smooths the workflow for all employees
His charm smoothed her transition into the new role
The mediator smoothed tensions between the arguing parties
They need to smooth out disagreements before proceeding

definitions: kill or suffocate by depriving of air or covering the breathing passages
cover something thickly or extensively with a layer of something
suppress or stifle something completely preventing its expression or development
examples: The thick smoke nearly smothered the trapped firefighters
She accidentally smothered the plant by overwatering it
He smothered his pancakes with maple syrup and butter
Snow smothered the landscape in a white blanket
She tried to smother her feelings of disappointment
The government attempted to smother dissent among citizens

definitions: make dirty marks or stains on something by rubbing
blur or become indistinct by rubbing or spreading
examples: The child smudged chocolate fingerprints all over the wall
Rain smudged the ink on the important documents
She accidentally smudged her mascara while crying
The artist deliberately smudged the charcoal for effect

definitions: move goods illegally into or out of a country avoiding customs
bring something or someone somewhere secretly and often illegally
examples: Criminals smuggle drugs across the border every day
They were caught smuggling diamonds in their luggage
She smuggled snacks into the movie theater
He smuggled his phone into the exam room

definitions: eat a small amount of food between regular meals
examples: Children often snack on fruit after school
She snacks constantly while working from home
Avoid snacking late at night for better sleep
They snacked on cheese and crackers during the party

definitions: catch or tear something on a sharp or rough projection
obtain or catch something quickly or unexpectedly, often by luck
examples: She snagged her sweater on a nail sticking out
The fishing line snagged on underwater branches
He managed to snag the last ticket to the concert
She snagged a great deal during the clearance sale

definitions: move with a twisting motion like a snake along a path
extend in curves and turns through an area or landscape
examples: The river snakes through the valley for many miles
The line of customers snaked around the entire building
The mountain road snakes dangerously up the steep cliff
Smoke snaked upward from the chimney into the sky

definitions: break suddenly and completely with a sharp cracking sound
make a sudden sharp cracking sound or movement
speak to someone in an angry, sharp, or irritable manner
take a photograph quickly and informally with a camera
examples: The dry branch snapped under his weight immediately
She snapped the pencil in half during the argument
The flag snapped loudly in the strong wind
He snapped his fingers to get her attention
Don't snap at me just because you're stressed
She snapped back angrily when criticized unfairly
Tourists were snapping photos of the famous monument
He quickly snapped a selfie with the celebrity

definitions: catch an animal or person in a trap or snare device
entangle or involve someone in a difficult or compromising situation
examples: Hunters snare rabbits using wire loops in the forest
The poacher was caught snaring protected birds illegally
The con artist snared elderly victims in his schemes
She felt snared by obligations she couldn't escape

definitions: quickly seize something in a rude or eager way
steal something by grabbing it suddenly and running away
examples: She snatched the letter from his hands angrily
The child snatched cookies when nobody was looking
The thief snatched her purse and ran down the street
Someone snatched his phone right out of his hand

definitions: move quietly and carefully to avoid being seen or heard
do something or take something secretly without permission
examples: The cat sneaked through the garden stalking a bird
He sneaked out of the house after midnight
She sneaked a look at his private diary
Students tried to sneak food into the library

definitions: suddenly and involuntarily expel air from the nose and mouth
examples: She sneezed several times due to her allergies
The pepper made everyone in the kitchen sneeze
He sneezed loudly during the quiet ceremony
Cats sometimes sneeze when they have respiratory infections

definitions: draw air audibly through the nose to detect a smell
show contempt or disdain by drawing air through the nose
examples: The dog sniffed around the yard searching for treats
She sniffed the milk to check if it was fresh
He sniffed disdainfully at their amateur attempts
Critics sniffed at the movie's predictable plot

definitions: shoot at someone from a concealed position at long range
make petty critical comments about someone in an indirect way
examples: Enemy soldiers sniped at our troops from the rooftops
The hunter sniped birds from his hidden position
Politicians constantly snipe at each other through social media
Coworkers sniped about the new manager behind her back

definitions: secretly inform on someone's wrongdoing to an authority figure
steal something small or of little value opportunistically
examples: Someone snitched on the students who were cheating
He snitched to the boss about employees taking breaks
Kids often snitch cookies from the jar before dinner
She snitched a pen from the hotel room

definitions: play the cue sport of snooker with colored balls on a table
deceive or trick someone into a disadvantageous position cleverly
examples: They snookered for hours at the local pub
He snookers professionally in international tournaments
The salesman completely snookered us with his smooth talk
Don't let them snooker you into signing that contract

definitions: investigate or look around furtively in someone's private affairs
examples: She was caught snooping through her roommate's diary
Neighbors love to snoop on each other's business
The detective snooped around the suspect's apartment carefully
Stop snooping in matters that don't concern you

definitions: swim underwater using a snorkel tube to breathe air from above
examples: We snorkeled among tropical fish in the coral reef
She loves to snorkel in clear Caribbean waters
They snorkeled for hours exploring the underwater caves
Tourists often snorkel to see marine life up close

definitions: fall from the sky as snow precipitation in cold weather
overwhelm someone with a large quantity of something, especially flattery
examples: It snowed heavily throughout the night covering everything
The weather forecast says it will snow tomorrow
The salesman tried to snow us with technical jargon
Don't let him snow you with false compliments

definitions: increase rapidly in size or importance like a rolling snowball
throw balls of compressed snow at someone or something playfully
examples: The small problem snowballed into a major crisis quickly
Debt can snowball if you only pay minimum amounts
Children love to snowball each other during winter
We snowballed passing cars when we were young

definitions: ride down snow-covered slopes on a snowboard for sport or recreation
examples: She learned to snowboard during her winter vacation
Professional athletes snowboard in competitions worldwide
They snowboard every weekend at the local ski resort
He prefers to snowboard rather than ski downhill

definitions: reject or ignore someone in a disdainful or contemptuous manner
deliberately ignore or fail to acknowledge someone socially
examples: She snubbed his invitation to dinner with cold silence
The committee snubbed several qualified candidates unfairly
He felt snubbed when she walked past without greeting
Celebrities sometimes snub fans who approach them rudely

definitions: extinguish a flame or light by pinching or covering it
inhale something, especially powdered tobacco, through the nose
examples: She snuffed the candle before leaving the room
Wind snuffed out the campfire during the storm
Victorian gentlemen would snuff tobacco at social gatherings
Some people still snuff medicinal herbs for health benefits

definitions: immerse something in liquid for an extended period of time
absorb liquid gradually through pores or small openings
charge someone an excessive or unfair amount of money
examples: Soak the beans overnight before cooking them tomorrow
She soaked in a hot bath after the workout
The sponge soaked up all the spilled water
Rain soaked through his jacket within minutes
The hotel soaked tourists with outrageous prices
They really soaked us for those concert tickets

definitions: wash or clean something using soap and water thoroughly
apply soap to something in preparation for washing or cleaning
examples: She carefully soaped the dirty dishes before rinsing
The nurse soaped her hands for the required time
He soaped himself thoroughly in the shower
Soap the stain well before putting it in the washer

definitions: fly or rise high in the air with little effort
increase rapidly to a very high level or amount
examples: Eagles soar majestically above the mountain peaks
The glider soared silently on the thermal currents
Housing prices soared during the economic boom period
Her spirits soared when she received the good news

definitions: cry noisily while taking in short sudden breaths
examples: She sobbed uncontrollably after hearing the tragic news
The child sobbed himself to sleep after the nightmare
He could hear someone sobbing in the next room
She sobbed out her story to the counselor
